messages.message:
1. I get the thinking now! For me the confusion comes from the fact that in a project we are only assigning a 'test value', which is just a placeholder. It requires the user to think a step ahead to understand the point of this i.e. its not about the dev app, its about a generic value so that we can use the same app in Prod later. This is not intuitive (but I agree its important)
2. I think tool-tips or something should help here. I noticed the name of a secret also has to be Pythonic, but if I have a space I'm not told why this isn't allowed. The 'why' for these failures is quite important
Another piece of feedback: if I run the app that uses a secret without specifying a value to be used for a key, I should get a warning or error. It's quite easy to miss or forget about here

We anticipate there are scenarios where a user wants to pass through an undefined value so I don't want to add that validation yet, but we have considered adding a "required" property to keys that would force you to specify a value before running or get a validation error. We will put that on the backlog!
@Natasha we should think some more about a good way to show actual error messages for validation errors in key/value cells
